docs.lead_paragraph: John Edwards, a rich man who often talks about the ordinary people he represented in his years as a trial lawyer here, faced an unusual problem nine years ago. While preparing for a big medical malpractice trial, he grew concerned that his clients' wealth might alienate the jury, he told a legal newspaper here at the time. His response was both methodical and political. He convened a series of three focus groups to help him hone his plea to a Charlotte, N.C., jury that it not cut its award based on the fact that the father of the injured boy in the case owned a Volvo dealership.

headline.main: Edwards's Lawyerly Style Drew Fierce Foes and Fans

docs.abstract: Sen John Edwards was known in 20-year career as trial lawyer for rigorous preparation of cases and for good eye in choosing cases with largest verdict possibilities; pioneered use of focus groups in North Carolina and elevated selection of clients to science, looking for grave harm, clear culpability and plaintiffs, often poor, whose stories would appeal to jury; list of some of more than forty multimillion-dollar verdicts and settlements he won, several involving birth injuries; photo in 1997 with couple awarded $25 million for catastrophic injuries to 5-year-old daughter from defective swimming-pool drain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New government estimates suggest that employers will reduce or eliminate prescription drug benefits for 3.8 million retirees when Medicare offers such coverage in 2006. That represents one-third of all the retirees with employer-sponsored drug coverage, according to documents from the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline.main: DRUG LAW IS SEEN LEADING TO CUTS IN RETIREE PLANS

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Department estimates employers will cut or end prescription drug benefits for 3.8 million retirees, about third of all retires with employer-sponsored drug coverage, when Medicare offers such coverage in 2006; senior department officials have been saying for weeks that federal subsidies will induce more employers to continue offering retiree drug benefits; Rep Pete Stark holds new law apparently will force millions of retirees out of comprehensive drug coverage into flawed, inadequate program; Republican supporters of new law and many employers say it will combat trend of employers' dropping retiree coverage; House votes to let Americans import prescription drugs from other countries, where prices are often lower; Republican leaders say provision, opposed by Pres Bush, will probably be dropped from bill in negotiations with Senate (M)
docs.snippet: New government estimates suggest that employers will reduce or eliminate prescription drug benefits for 3.8 million retirees when Medicare offers such coverage in 2006.    That represents one-third of all the retirees with employer-sponsored drug...

docs.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed this week in a Manhattan court paints a picture of an ingratiating Roman Catholic priest on the Upper East Side who separated an elderly parishioner from nearly half a million dollars. Filed on Monday in State Supreme Court, the suit accuses Msgr. John G. Woolsey, the pastor of St. John the Martyr parish at 71st Street and Second Avenue, of inducing the parishioner, Rose Cale, to give him stock and $100,000 to buy a condominium on the Jersey Shore when she was in her 80's. It also names the New York Archdiocese, saying it was responsible for the priest's actions, and asks for restitution and damages.

headline.main: Suit Assails Clergy for Hold Over Wealthy

docs.abstract: Suit is filed by estate Rose Cale accusing Msgr John G Woolsey of St John the Martyr parish in Manhattan of inducing Cale, then in her 80's, to give him stock and $100,000 to buy shoreside condominium; also names New York Archdiocese, saying it was responsible for Woolsey's actions; priests comment on tricky situations that arise when parishioners want to give money; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If marriage is officially redefined to provide benefits for homosexual partners, couldn't others claim a right to such benefits? Someone who signs a paper pledging fidelity to a friend, for example, might well ask why sexuality should be a factor in allowing or refusing coverage under the friend's health insurance.

headline.main: Gay Marriage: Battle in the Capital

docs.abstract: Edward Styles letter favors ban on gay marriage; says marriage benefits are not reward for monogamous lifestyle, but means to care for dependent young (July 12 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: The WebMD Corporation, which manages electronic transactions between doctors and insurers, agreed yesterday to buy the information-technology company ViPS Inc. for $160 million, to gain business from the government's Medicare program. The purchase price includes assumed liabilities, said Jennifer Meyer, a spokeswoman for WebMD, based in Elmwood Park, N.J. The company would not elaborate, she said. ViPS, a closely held company based in Baltimore, had 2003 sales of about $59 million and employs about 400 people. The acquisition will allow WebMD to add customers, like the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance providers. ViPS offers consulting services, claims processing and fraud prevention software to more than 65 percent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield health plans and all Medicare carriers. Shares of WebMD rose 1 cent, to $8.59. WebMD, which also operates health-information Web sites, will complete the purchase within a month, Ms. Meyer said. The acquisition will be WebMD's fifth since July 2003.

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Deals: WebMD To Buy ViPS For $160 Million

docs.lead_paragraph: Once Britons wore their stoicism on their sleeves, acting almost as if they would rather die than complain. ''For my own sake I do not regret this journey,'' the great failed explorer Capt. Robert Falcon Scott wrote in the journal found beside his frozen corpse in Antarctica in 1912, ''which has shown that Englishmen can endure hardships, help one another, and meet death with as great a fortitude as ever in the past.'' But there is a growing sense that the famous British habit of stoutly taking it on the chin is going the way of the farthing, the gentleman in the bowler hat and the empire. Just as in the United States, whose citizens have never been shy about sticking up for themselves, complaining is becoming a way of life in Britain.

headline.main: Britain's Stiff Upper Lip Is Being Twisted Into a Snarl

docs.abstract: Britons appear to be abandoning ideal of stiff upper lip for which they were famous and adopting culture of complaint and litigation; some fear that people are losing their sense of personal responsibility and community spirit; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Putting ill-gotten gains to public use, Nassau County is using $1.5 million of restitution from convicts in a corruption case to pay for safeguards in government spending. The money comes from convicts in a case involving a bogus health insurance deal that cost the county tens of millions of dollars. The biggest sum from the restitution is $1.25 million from the former Suffolk County Republican Party chairman, William Michael Blake, his brother, John, and his son, David. Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, announced yesterday that it would be spent on a team of accountants to assess county agencies' operations and devise stricter controls. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Bad Money Put To Good Use

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is poised to approve an international trade agreement that could have the effect of thwarting a goal pursued by many lawmakers of both parties: the import of inexpensive prescription drugs to help millions of Americans without health insurance. The agreement, negotiated with Australia by the Bush administration, would allow pharmaceutical companies to prevent imports of drugs to the United States and also to challenge decisions by Australia about what drugs should be covered by the country's health plan, the prices paid for them and how they can be used.

headline.main: Trade Agreement May Undercut Importing of Inexpensive Drugs

docs.abstract: International trade agreement about to be approved in Congress could thwart goal of lawmakers of both parties: import of inexpensive prescription drugs to help millions of Americans without health insurance; agreement, negotiated by Bush administration with Australia, would allow pharmaceutical companies to prevent imports of drugs to US and also to challenge decisions by Australia about what drugs should be covered by country's health plan, prices paid for them and how they can be used; plan represents administration's model for strengthening protection of expensive brand-name drugs in wealthy countries, where biggest profits can be made; US has for first time challenged how foreign industrialized country operates its national health program to provide inexpensive drugs to its own citizens; partly because US does not have such a plan, Americans without insurance pay some of world's highest prices for brand-name prescription drugs; lawmakers have only recently realized that proposed Australia trade accord could have major implications for health policy and programs in US; administration wants to raise price of drugs overseas to spread burden of research and development that is borne disproportionately by US (M)
